Advancement is possible for those who really wants.
cons:
No company is perfect, they work hard already to fix their flaws. Problems are not worth being mentioned.

If I can mention one though it would be the high roll of employee change (in some specific departments).

review_title: Love where this organization is heading
pros: Positive, creative, dedicated individuals that care about the whole person. A part of a strong international network, solid education for students, and positive experience for all. As with any organization people can be part of a solution to a problem or part of a problem to a solution. The people here are problem solvers with a hard-working ethic, balanced with positive attitudes and a healthy work-life balance.
cons: As with any growing organization, the growth can sometimes lead too many things to do and only so much time to do it. But it's a good problem to have and something that the school is aware of and making sure that we are all moving forward together.

pros: There are not any pros.
cons: Students are ripped off and misinformed about their courses, teachers are underpaid and exploited, and staff are bullied. Management doesn't know what it's doing. And frankly, doesn't care. Do not believe any positive reviews here. No one who leaves does so with a positive attitude. And people leave all the time. I left because finally I could.

pros: good communication for everyone working and studying
cons: sometimes people are not available to help at the time.

review_title: The culture is very detrimental to the mental health of the staff
pros: There are some amazing people to work with and learn from.
cons: Culture is extremely marginalizing and this is very top-down. The leadership of the college is unable to foster a positive work environment throughout the school and very often one of the good people referred to above would quit on this culture in search of a less aggressive environment and to protect their mental health (a very recurring theme at this place which is disturbing). You will often find that the high performing dedicated employees are the first to quit, and the incompetent, insecure and passive-aggressive ones end up "ruling" with little done by leadership to enable the former and curb the negative effects of the latter. Its also interesting how they would cut benefits, support programs, variable income (bonuses etc.) to the staff to favour one or two of the "privileged" higher-ups.

pros:
- Nice campus 
- Some of your coworkers will be really nice 
- some long term staff that are committed to making the school good 
- registrar office and finance are very diligent, orderly, and seemingly the only department without gossip
- HR is helpful and asks how people are
- president seems nice and walks around asking how everyone is
cons:
Wow, where do I start.
- the bullying and gossip that goes on from the admissions team is constant and makes it unpleasant to be at work
- general lots of gossip going on in every other department
- some managers/directors seem to have no idea what they’re doing, can’t lead, and don’t resolve employee issues 
- tons of complaints about managers 
- extremely lacking in organization, no one knows anything, there’s no training so doing your job well is difficult 
- so many unprofessional coworkers, sexist comments, rude behaviour, inappropriate attitudes 
- even if you have a low salary you have to work so much overtime to do your job

review_title: Extremely unhealthy  environment for students and staff!
pros: There are some staff who care
cons: This company has the worst management I have ever seen. The staff is disengaged and are employed there just to collect a pay check. The employees don’t receive any direction and constantly gossip and backstab each other. There is absolutely nothing professional about this school. It is a top down run organization where the leadership team is disingenuous to lower level staff.  Don’t expect any of them to greet you with a friendly hello or genuinely ask you how you are doing. If you do have feedback for them, they will not follow through or hear what the good employees who actually care about the students have to say. They are there to pump money out of international students with mental health issues.  Staff do not have knowledge about what’s going on at the school and are constantly frustrated. As a result, students get poor quality education.

pros: I've worked here for almost a year now, and I have to say it is one of the most positive environments I've ever worked in. Everyone here is so helpful and fun to be around.  The lunch room is the best because everyone is always laughing and sharing. Plus management got us a state of the art massage chair. The work itself can get a little stressful with deadlines on the job. The work can also be rewarding. Ultimately I'm really happy with where I work.
cons: Not much opportunity for promotion.

job_title: Administrative Worker (Office Gladiator) in Vancouver, BC
pros: I joined La Salle Vancouver not too long ago now. Its been brilliant since my coming aboard. Firstly it is in a beautiful city, with so many opportunities for social clubs and societies. Beautiful college, magical atmosphere, lots of educational excitement alongside very diverse colleagues. You get to form a great connection with all the staff to help with your personal progress and learning! Not to mention the gallery, restaurant, and events that are all worthy as tourist attractions for those interested. My office desk job makes me feel like a superstar.
cons: Wifi covers a lot of ground but can be on and off.  Shame there isn't a student round table for staff feedback.

pros: LCI Education has done a great job transitioning this institution by providing focused leadership and direction with quality of education, student experience and employee satisfaction at the forefront.  From my perspective, current leadership has put a lot of resources into institutional research and development to help achieve its goals.
cons: With any transition comes change, which has at times not been easy. But as stated above LaSalle College Vancouver's current leadership has stepped up to address issues brought forward through change (past or present) head on.

pros: Lifestyle is great; not a lot of hours actually in class. One naturally garners a lot of satisfaction from teaching, in my opinion.
cons: It gets tiring to work at a place where everyone, teachers and students are all pretty dissatisfied by the administration.

pros: - located downtown, international presence decent cafeteria
cons:
- Abusive micronamangement, no support
- Employees overloaded
- Not concerned with their employees' personal lives, not one bit
- Poor perks, force employees to take their vacation days on certain dates (and if they don't have days accumulated, that's unpaid vacation, no more than 2 consecutive vacation weeks)
- Some employees had access to their benefits 1 or 2 months later than they were supposed to, which is not acceptable
-No training
-People getting fired for random reasons
-Hiring highly qualified people and underpaying them to do basic work
-Pay is not competitive at all

review_title: If you're thinking of starting a 3D career, avoid this school
job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Vancouver, BC
pros: I can't say there are any. Close to a skytrain station?
cons:
This review is intended mostly for future students that are looking to start a career in 3D - VFX, animation, games. 
I've been a part time instructor at LaSalle (formerly The Art Institute of Vancouver) for a lot of years. I can only say that if you're looking for a 3D career this school is not for you.  The only requirement to get in is to be able to pay for the program. As long as you qualify for a student loan, you're in! 
You will be misled from the moment you apply. The admissions office will talk to you about job opportunities and make everything sound peachy (it is literally their job). The fact is, they have very little knowledge about the industry but, mostly likely, you have none, so you'll be tempted to believe what they say. Don't do that! They are in no position to know.
Just like most other private school in this sector, you get out what you put in. But at LaSalle you will be required to put in the bare minimum. While that might sound good (who doesn't want to pass a class with minimum effort?) you'll end up with 2 years of your life spent in school, $50,000+ in debt and no prospect for a career since the work you'll end up will be far below any industry standard. 
Also for the first 4 terms you'll have a lot of full-time instructors that have been there for a long time. While this is fine in itself, the majority of them have not kept in touch with an industry that changes really fast, so the methods that you'll learn will most likely be obsolete or just plain wrong. Also, they won't bother pushing you to do better. The school standard is to pass anyone that submits any work, regardless of the quality of that work. In the long run, this is a route to disaster for your career. From what I can see the school is trying to turn every student into a button pusher, no creativity whatsoever. The button pushing will get you results very fast, however, no one wants to hire button pushers. 
This is about as far as it can get from what's supposed to be an art school. 
As far as an Instructor position goes (part time) if you're goal is to do the bare minimum for 4 hours at a time and you don't mind dealing with students that don't really speak English, then this is the job for you! Your hourly rate will be somewhere around $50 an hour, but as far as I've experienced, there are no rate increases. Or at least I never got one since I started. They value you very little. As long as you play by their rules and pass students, you should be good.

pros: Vancouver campus is a great place to work, the staff work together well to overcome any and all challenges that are brought forward. There is support from all facets of the in-house staff.
cons: No windows in the inside offices. The faculty room is a little dark. In all fairness HR did give me a tour and showed me the faculty room and classrooms so I was prepared.
